articles.author: Andrew Osborn
articles.description: Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev, who has sometimes raised the spectre of a nuclear conflict over Ukraine, said on Sunday that Moscow would have to use a nuclear weapon if Kyiv's ongoing counter-offensive was a success.
articles.title: Russia's Medvedev: We'd have to use a nuclear weapon if Ukrainian offensive was a success

articles.author: Alexander Tanas
articles.description: Russia's embassy in Moldova has announced it will temporarily stop providing appointments for consular matters in what Moldovan officials say is a situation linked to the order by the country's authorities to reduce staff.
articles.title: Russian embassy in Moldova to suspend consular appointments

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: The Danish government will seek to "find a legal tool" that would enable authorities to prevent the burning of copies of the Koran in front of other countries' embassies in Denmark, Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen told the national broadcaster DR on Sunday.
articles.title: Denmark to look for 'legal tool' to prevent Koran burnings

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: The largest party representing North Macedonia's ethnic Albanian minority offered to pull its ministers from the government to meet a demand from the opposition to clear the way for European Union membership talks.
articles.title: Ethnic Albanian party in North Macedonia offers deal to clear the way to join EU

articles.author: Steve Scherer
articles.description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made massive changes to his cabinet last week in a move political analysts say is more theater than substance, but the Liberal leader's close advisers say it shows his determination to seek a fourth election victory.
articles.title: Canada's Trudeau sets sights on fourth election fight with Cabinet refresh

articles.author: Libby George, Marc Jones
articles.description: Israel's economy may face ratings downgrades, falling foreign investment and a weaker tech sector if turmoil arising from the government's contentious judicial reforms continues, investors and analysts warn.
articles.title: Israel's judicial reform turmoil threatens economic growth, investment

articles.author: Dan Williams
articles.description: A top Israeli lawmaker said on Sunday that any forging of relations with Saudi Arabia did not appear imminent, citing what he described as sticking points in negotiations currently being held between Riyadh and U.S. mediators.
articles.title: Israeli deputy says normalisation with Saudis does not appear imminent

articles.author: Andrew Osborn
articles.description: Russia's Defence Ministry said it had brought down three Ukrainian drones early on Sunday that had tried to strike Moscow in the second such attack in a week, which damaged a high rise building reported to house government offices.
articles.title: Russia says it downs Ukrainian drones, Moscow buildings hit

articles.author: Tommy Wilkes
articles.description: Banks working to develop global standards on accounting for carbon emissions in bond or stock sale underwriting have voted to exclude most of these emissions from their own carbon footprint, three people familiar with the matter said.
articles.title: Exclusive: Banks vote to limit accounting of emissions in bond and stock sales

articles.author: Robyn Mak
articles.description: China faces a long slog to artificial intelligence supremacy. It wants to be a leader in the field by 2030 and this month unveiled new rules governing the technology that are less onerous than expected. But closed online ecosystems, Beijing’s controls on internet content and U.S. curbs on semiconductor exports to the world’s second largest economy will hamper progress.
articles.title: Chinese AI arrives by stealth, not with a bang
